chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a woman with hair loss in primary care?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• For a woman presenting with hair loss in primary care, the diagnosis of androgenetic alopecia is usually made from the history and clinical findings alone.
  • Take a detailed history to assess the severity, impact, and possible causes of hair loss. Ask about the following:
    • Timing and pattern of the hair loss — including onset, speed of progression (which is usually gradual), and scalp areas affected.
    • Past medical problems, including systemic disease (such as a recent severe infection) or endocrine disorders (such as hypothyroidism).
    • Family history of hair loss.
    • Use of medication (such as antidepressants, anticoagulants, chemotherapy, oral contraceptives, anabolic steroids, or carbimazole) and dietary habits (such as excessive dieting).
    • The normal hair care routine, including changes in hairstyle to compensate for alopecia and use of hair care procedures or products.
    • Gynaecological/obstetric history (to help identify any potential hormonal imbalance), including:
      • Age of menarche and menstrual pattern (prior to using hormonal contraception).
      • Use of contraception, hormone replacement therapy, or fertility treatment.
      • History of pregnancy or infertility.
    • Previous features of androgen excess, for example excessive facial and body hair (hirsutism) or severe acne.
    • The psychological impact of hair loss and the impact on quality of life.
  • Assess the pattern and distribution of hair thinning and inspect the scalp.
    • Typically, androgenetic alopecia in women presents as thinning in the density of hair at the crown and frontal scalp, and widening of the central parting with retention of the frontal hairline.
    • The degree of hair loss can be assessed using the Ludwig scale. Hair loss is often diffuse.
    • The presentation may vary, however, and less frequent, atypical patterns are:
      • Thinning and widening of the central part of the scalp with breach of frontal hairline (Christmas tree pattern).
      • Thinning associated with bi-temporal recession (male pattern). See the section on The Hamilton-Norwood Scale in the CKS topic on Alopecia, androgenetic - male.
    • Short, thin, vellus hairs may be present (but are more common in males).
    • Women tend not to develop completely bald areas. Hair density often remains greatest over the occipital scalp.
    • Shedding, if present, is generally mild. 
  • Consider use of the pull test (depending on clinical judgement).
  • Assess for existing features of androgen excess.
  • Suspect an underlying cause or alternative diagnosis for the hair loss if there is:
    • Profound shedding or a rapid onset of hair loss which may indicate telogen effluvium.
    • Temporal hair thinning which may indicate traction, frontal fibrosing alopecia, or hypothyroidism.
    • Inflammation, papules or pustules, scaling, or scarring of the scalp.
    • Systemic disease, such as a recent severe infection, iron deficiency, or hypothyroidism.
    • Exposure to, or a change of medication.
    • Extreme dietary habits or rapid weight loss.
  • Consider whether any investigations are required.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Features of androgen excess
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Features of androgen excess include:
    • Excessive facial and body hair (hirsutism). See the CKS topic on Hirsutism for more information.
    • Severe acne. See the CKS topic on Acne vulgaris for more information.
    • Seborrhoea of scalp and skin. See the CKS topic on Seborrhoeic dermatitis for more information.
    • Virilization.
    • Menstrual irregularities.
    • Infertility. See the CKS topic on Infertility for more information.
    • Galactorrhoea.
    • History of polycystic ovary syndrome. See the CKS topic on Polycystic ovary syndrome for more information.

[Blume-Peytavi et al, 2010; Levy and Emer, 2013; BMJ, 2015]

subChapters.htmlHeader: The Ludwig scale
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• The degree of female alopecia can be assessed using the Ludwig Scale, which ranges from stage 1 to 3 [Ludwig, 1977].
    • Stage 1 — Minimal 
      • Thinning of hair is seen from the anterior part of the crown with slight widening of the parting width. Women tend to hide the frontal area of hair loss by combing the hair forward, exposing a visible area of alopecia in the anterior centroparietal area while the frontal hairline is maintained.
    • Stage 2 — Moderate 
      • Thinning of the crown has gradually become more evident because of an increase in the number of thin and short hairs. Combing the hair forward is less effective.
    • Stage 3 — Intense
      • The crown becomes almost totally bald. There is significant widening of the parting width, but the frontal hairline is maintained. Combing the hair forward is not very effective.

subChapters.htmlHeader: The pull test
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Although the 'pull test' does not provide a definitive diagnosis of androgenetic alopecia, it is a crude tool to determine the ongoing activity and severity of any type of hair loss. 
    • It is usually negative in androgenetic alopecia, except for affected areas of the scalp, where a moderate degree of telogen hair shedding may occur during active periods of the disease.
    • A diffusely positive pull test requires investigation for telogen effluvium (but androgenetic alopecia may still coexist).
    • The test is of value only in experienced hands, as it shows high inter-observer variation and is influenced by hair shampooing and washing. Examiners should standardize their own procedure. 
  • The 'pull test' technique:
    • Tug a bundle of approximately 50–100 hairs firmly, but not forcibly, away from the scalp, sliding the fingers along the hair shaft. 
    • The test is positive if more than 3 hairs are pulled away from the scalp (although up to 10% of grasped hairs may come off) and indicates active hair shedding.

[Blume-Peytavi et al, 2010; BMJ, 2015; Ramos et al, 2015]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: The recommendations on how to diagnose and assess androgenetic alopecia in women are based on expert opinion in a European consensus guideline for the diagnostic evaluation of androgenetic alopecia in men, women, and adolescents [Blume-Peytavi et al, 2010], expert opinion in review articles for the diagnosis and management of androgenetic alopecia [Camacho-Martinez, 2009; Hillman and Blume-Peytavi, 2009; Herskovitz et al, 2013; Levy and Emer, 2013], and the British Medical Journal Best practice article for androgenetic alopecia [BMJ, 2015].
